awd_titl_txt: The Meaning of Verbal Roots Across Languages
awd_abstract_narration:
Language serves not just as a means of communication but also a window into how humans perceive the world. Verbs have been a rich source of information about how humans categorize events, and one tantalizing result of work on verb meaning is that the possible meanings a verb can have are not arbitrary. Rather, there are recurring meaning components of high generality that define classes of verbs according to the broad situation type being described, including cause and effect, bodily action, and possession, and verbs within a class tend to have shared grammatical behaviors. Individual verbs within a class are distinguished by idiosyncratic details that fill in the specifics of the broader situation, e.g. the name of a specific action, usually with few grammatical ramifications. However, how general and idiosyncratic components combine in the meaning of a verb is still not well understood, nor is the space of what idiosyncratic meanings an individual verb within a class can have, including how distinct general and verb-specific meanings even are. Understanding these issues has consequences for our understanding of human languages, and can serve practical purposes, particularly in relation to search engine technology and machine translation.

This project addresses these lacunae by examining the idiosyncratic meanings of verbs describing change-of-state (e.g. break, redden) and caused possession (e.g. give, send), which have been claimed to exemplify possible limits on idiosyncratic meanings. The methodology involves (i) in depth studies of these verbs in English and Kinyarwanda (chosen for its rich verbal morphology), the latter through field work, and (ii) a broad survey of change-of-state verbs in a genealogically balanced 100 language sample drawn from existing published reference materials. The goal is to isolate general and idiosyncratic meaning in verbs through inferential and morphological patterns. The results will be integrated into a theory of how verb meanings are composed using modern techniques in compositional semantics. The expectation based on pilot data is that while idiosyncratic meanings are not limited in terms of their literal content, they fall into limited types regarding their relation to the rest of the verb's meaning, making some predictions about possible and impossible verbs.

Overview 

This project explored the underlying nature of verb meanings. Verbs describe and catalog events around us every day, and serve as the most central words in nearly every sentence. Linguistic theorizing about verbs dating back thousands of years has observed that verbs with similar meanings fall into distinct classes based on their shared semantics, e.g. verbs that describe cause-effect scenarios like shatter, actions like run, or possession like have. Verbs in the same class tend to have similar grammatical properties in terms of what kinds of noun phrases they combine with, what prefixes or suffixes they take, and which prepositions they occur with, among other things. Within a class, each specific verb differs from the others mainly in terms of the specific meaning it contributes, corresponding to often fine-grained distinctions in human experience, e.g. crack vs. shatter, jog vs. run, have vs. need. These slight distinctions in meaning are usually assumed to be linguistically uninteresting. For this reason, theories of verb meaning that explore what counts as a possible or impossible verb and why have focused more on the broader meanings of verb classes than on the subtleties of individual verbs. A common analysis is that specific combinations of noun phrases, prefixes, suffixes, and prepositions themselves define verb classes, constituting a grammatical "template" that introduces a shared semantics into which specific verbs can be inserted. The individual verb just fills in the idiosyncratic, real world details within that template. This standard analysis provides a simple, elegant theory for what a verb will mean within a given template and what kinds of verbs should be possible at all, placing an emphasis on how predictable a verb's meaning is based on its grammatical properties. Our project challenged the assumptions underlying this theory by looking at how the idiosyncratic part of a verb's meaning contributes to the formation of classes that matter for the structure of individual languages.

Outcomes

We conducted two case studies, with a goal of showing that idiosyncratic verb meanings can be significant to the verb'sgrammatical behavior. A study of verbs that describe cause-effect scenarios showed that there are at least two kinds of effects. One class (e.g. redden, soften) describe changes into states that could have existed independent of any event by which they came about, while another (e.g. shatter, fry) describe changes into states that only ever come about through some explicit event. In a balanced sample of 88 languages we showed that verbs falling into the two classes consistently show distinct grammatical and semantic properties, demonstrating a deep universality of the distinction. A second study explored verbs of giving (e.g. give, loan) in English (Indo-European) and Kinyarwanda (Bantu). In English giving can be expressed via two distinct templates: an indirect object templateindicating caused possession (e.g. She loaned me a book) or a preposition to indicating motion towards (e.g. She threw a ball to the third baseman). Kinyarwanda has corresponding expressions that are similar, but show an even wider and more varied usage. Yet we showed that in both languages individual verbs shape, expand, and alter those two broad templatic expressions in ways that suggest that notions like "caused possession" and "motion towards" are coming from the specific verbs themselves. In both case studies, the meanings of some idiosyncratic verbs thus overlap partly or entirely with the meaning of the template they occur in, calling into question whether the concept of a grammatical template is really a part of the human language faculty.

Based on our findings, we developed a new theory of verb meanings that still maintains the distinction between a grammatical template and the specific verbs found in it, but where the meanings of each are intertwined with the other to form a complete meaning through specific semantic processes that we outline in detail. The resulting theory still admits sets of possible and impossible verb types, and predictions about the relationship of form to meaning, albeit where generalizations about verb classes arise both from templates and a classification of individual verb meanings. Along the way, our project also expanded our understanding of the semantic ingredients that make up templates and individual verb classes, introducing new theories of what constitutes cause-effect scenarios and motion towards, and what their linguistic relevance is.

These results should have an impact on linguistic issues that revolve around word meaning. Within linguistic theory this includes new theorizing on the lexical semantic basis of syntax, and how meaning is inferred from word choice. In more applied areas, this new understanding of verb meaning could have practical benefits for language learning, human-computer interaction, and computer processing of natural language text and speech. Furthermore, by building our results on cross-linguistic comparison, we have contributed new data on underdocumented languages towards the development of a richer understanding of word meaning for all human languages.
